title: Companion to the Book
text: Companion Book “Investigating Statistical Concepts, Applications, Methods” package collates presents functions ISCAM alongside data used alongside textbook. don’t know function e.g. EXAMPLE() works, can write ?EXAMPLE console get help. can also find website. Also look textbook/Canvas/homework see function used. can load workspace running
code: # uncomment and run this line *once* to install the package install.packages("ISCAM")  # the following loads the package. You need to do this every time you want to use ISCAM functions library(ISCAM) load(url("http://www.rossmanchance.com/iscam4/ISCAM.RData"))

title: Cloud Seeding Data — CloudSeeding
text: lives depend rainfall. Consequently, scientists long investigated whether humans can intervene , needed, help nature produce rainfall. one study, researchers southern Florida explored whether injecting silver iodide cumulus clouds lead increased rainfall. 52 days judged suitable cloud seeding, target cloud identified plane flew target cloud order seed . Randomization used determine whether load seeding mechanism seed target cloud silver iodide day. Radar used measure volume rainfall selected cloud next 24 hours. results Simpson, Olsen, Eden, (1975) measure rainfall volume units acre-feet, “height” rain across one acre.

title: Cloud Seeding Data — CloudSeeding
code: CloudSeeding

title: Cloud Seeding Data — CloudSeeding
text: data frame 52 rows 2 columns: treatment Whether cloud seeded silver iodide . rainfall Volume rainfall next 24 hours, acre-feet.

title: Flint Michigan Lead Data — FlintMDEQ
text: Lead poisoning can serious problem associated drinking tap water. Many older water pipes made lead. time, pipes corrode, releasing lead drinking water. April 2014, city Flint Michigan switched water supply Flint River effort save money. Michigan Department Environmental Quality (MDEQ) tested water time declared safe drink. Officials supposed test least 100 homes, targeting risk. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)’s Lead Copper Rule states lead concentrations exceed action level 15 parts per billion (ppb) 10% homes sampled, actions must undertaken control corrosion, public must informed.

title: Flint Michigan Lead Data — FlintMDEQ
code: FlintMDEQ

title: Flint Michigan Lead Data — FlintMDEQ
text: data frame 71 rows 1 column: lead Lead concentration per household, measured parts per billion.

Additionally, functions accompanied plots. package designed used educational setting alongside ISCAM textbook.

title: Infant Data — Infant
text: study reported November 2007 issue Nature, researchers investigated whether infants take account individual’s actions towards others evaluating individual appealing aversive, perhaps laying foundation social interaction (Hamlin, Wynn, Bloom, 2007). words, children aren’t even yet talking still form impressions someone’s friendliness based actions? one component study, 10-month-old infants shown “climber” character (piece wood “googly” eyes glued onto ) make hill two tries. infants shown two scenarios climber’s next try, one climber pushed top hill another character (“helper” toy) one climber pushed back hill another character (“hinderer” toy). infant alternately shown two scenarios several times. child presented pieces wood (helper hinderer characters) asked pick one play . Videos demonstrating component study can found https://campuspress.yale.edu/infantlab/media/.

code: Infant

title: Infant Data — Infant
text: data frame 16 rows 1 column: choice Whether baby selected "helper" "hinderer" toy.

title: Sleep Deprivation Data — SleepDeprivation
text: Researchers established sleep deprivation harmful effect visual learning (subject consolidate information improve task). Stickgold, James, Hobson (2000) investigated whether subjects “make ” sleep deprivation getting full night’s sleep subsequent nights. study involved randomly assigning 21 subjects (volunteers ages 18 25) one two groups: one group deprived sleep night following training visual discrimination task, group permitted unrestricted sleep first night. groups allowed unrestricted sleep following two nights, re-tested third day. Subjects’ performance test recorded minimum time (milliseconds) stimuli appearing computer screen accurately report seen screen. Previous studies shown subjects deprived sleep performed significantly worse following day, clear long negative effects last. data presented improvements reaction times (milliseconds), negative value indicates decrease performance.

title: Sleep Deprivation Data — SleepDeprivation
code: SleepDeprivation

title: Sleep Deprivation Data — SleepDeprivation
text: data frame 21 rows 2 columns: sleepcondition sleep condition subject . improvement subject's improvement reaction times, measured milliseconds.

title: Sleep Deprivation Data — SleepDeprivation
text: https://www.nature.com/articles/nn1200_1237

what: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
title: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
text: addexp creates histogram x overlays exponential density function \(\lambda = \frac{1}{mean}\).

title: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
code: iscamaddexp(   x,   main = "Histogram with exponential curve",   xlab = deparse(substitute(x)),   bins = NULL )

title: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
text: x numeric vector representing data plotted. main Optional title plot xlab Optional x-axis label plot bins Optional number bins histogram.

title: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
text: histogram x overlayed exponential density function.

title: Overlay an Exponential Density Function on Histogram — iscamaddexp
code: set.seed(0) x <- rexp(100, rate = 0.5) iscamaddexp(x)  iscamaddexp(x, main = "Your Active Title", xlab = "Exponential Data", bins = 20)

what: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
title: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
text: binomnorm creates binomial distribution given inputs overlays normal approximation.

title: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
code: iscambinomnorm(k, n, prob, direction, verbose = TRUE)

title: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
text: k number successes interest n number trials prob success probability direction "", "", "two.sided" verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
text: plot binomial distribution overlayed normal approximation

title: Overlays Normal Approximation onto Binomial — iscambinomnorm
code: iscambinomnorm(k = 10, n = 20, prob = 0.5, direction = "two.sided")  #>  binomial: 1.176  #>  normal approx: 1  #>  normal approx with continuity: 1.177

title: Rejection Region for Binomial — iscambinompower
text: binompower determines rejection region corresponding level significance first probability shows binomial distribution shading corresponding region.

title: Rejection Region for Binomial — iscambinompower
code: iscambinompower(LOS, n, prob1, alternative, prob2 = NULL, verbose = TRUE)

title: Rejection Region for Binomial — iscambinompower
text: LOS numeric value representing level significance n numeric value representing sample size prob1 numeric value representing first probability alternative "less", "greater", "two.sided" prob2 numeric value representing second probability verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Rejection Region for Binomial — iscambinompower
text: plot binomial distribution rejection region highlighted.

title: Rejection Region for Binomial — iscambinompower
code: iscambinompower(LOS = 0.05, n = 20, prob1 = 0.5, alternative = "less")  #> Null: Probability 5 and below = 0.02069473   iscambinompower(LOS = 0.05, n = 20, prob1 = 0.5, alternative = "greater", prob2 = 0.75) #> Null: Probability 15 and above = 0.02069473   #> Alternative: Probability 15 and above = 0.6171727   iscambinompower(LOS = 0.10, n = 30, prob1 = 0.4, alternative = "two.sided")  #> Null: Probability in rejection region 0.09164   iscambinompower(LOS = 0.10, n = 30, prob1 = 0.4, alternative = "two.sided", prob2 = 0.2) #> Null: Probability in rejection region 0.09164   #> Alternative: Probability in rejection region 0.7608011

title: Calculate Binomial Tail Probabilities — iscambinomprob
text: binomprob calculates probability number success interest using binomial distribution plots distribution.

title: Calculate Binomial Tail Probabilities — iscambinomprob
code: iscambinomprob(k, n, prob, lower.tail, verbose = TRUE)

title: Calculate Binomial Tail Probabilities — iscambinomprob
text: k number successes interest. n number trials. prob success probability. Numeric 0 & 1. lower.tail Boolean finding probability (FALSE) (TRUE) inputted value (inclusive) verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Calculate Binomial Tail Probabilities — iscambinomprob
text: probability binomial distribution along graph distribution.

title: Calculate Binomial Tail Probabilities — iscambinomprob
code: iscambinomprob(k = 5, n = 20, prob = 0.4, lower.tail = TRUE)  #> Probability 5 and below = 0.125599  #> [1] 0.125599 iscambinomprob(k = 15, n = 30, prob = 0.3, lower.tail = FALSE)  #> Probability 15 and above = 0.01693731  #> [1] 0.01693731 iscambinomprob(k = 22, n = 25, prob = 0.9, lower.tail = TRUE)  #> Probability 22 and below = 0.4629059  #> [1] 0.4629059

title: Exact Binomial Test — iscambinomtest
text: binomtest calculates performs exact binomial test graphs binomial distribution /binomial confidence interval.

title: Exact Binomial Test — iscambinomtest
code: iscambinomtest(   observed,   n,   hypothesized = NULL,   alternative,   conf.level = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Exact Binomial Test — iscambinomtest
text: observed observed number successes sample proportion (assumed proportion value less one.) n number trials. hypothesized hypothesized probability success. alternative "less", "greater", "two.sided" conf.level Confidence level two-sided confidence interval. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Exact Binomial Test — iscambinomtest
text: list p-value along lower upper bound calculated confidence interval.

title: Exact Binomial Test — iscambinomtest
code: iscambinomtest(   observed = 17,   n = 25,   hypothesized = 0.5,   alternative = "greater" )  #>  #> Exact Binomial Test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 17, sample size = 25, sample proportion = 0.68 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi = 0.5  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi > 0.5  #> p-value: 0.053876   iscambinomtest(   observed = 12,   n = 80,   hypothesized = 0.10,   alternative = "two.sided",   conf.level = 0.95 )  #>  #> Exact Binomial Test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 12, sample size = 80, sample proportion = 0.15 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi = 0.1  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi <> 0.1  #> p-value: 0.13575  #> 95 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.079982 , 0.24736 )   iscambinomtest(   observed = 0.14,   n = 100,   hypothesized = 0.20,   alternative = "less" )  #>  #> Exact Binomial Test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 14, sample size = 100, sample proportion = 0.14 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi = 0.2  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi < 0.2  #> p-value: 0.080444   iscambinomtest(observed = 17, n = 25, conf.level = 0.95) #>  #> Exact Binomial Test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 17, sample size = 25, sample proportion = 0.68 #>  #> 95 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.465 , 0.8505 )    iscambinomtest(observed = 12, n = 80, conf.level = c(0.90, 0.95, 0.99)) #>  #> Exact Binomial Test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 12, sample size = 80, sample proportion = 0.15 #>  #> 90 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.088894 , 0.23168 )  #> 95 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.079982 , 0.24736 )  #> 99 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.06429 , 0.27922 )

title: Inverse Binomial Probability — iscaminvbinom

text: alpha probability interest. n number trials. prob probability success. lower.tail Boolean finding probability (FALSE) (TRUE) inputted value (inclusive) verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

text: numeric achieves stated probability

title: Inverse Binomial Probability — iscaminvbinom
code: iscaminvbinom(alpha = 0.05, n = 30, prob = 0.5, lower.tail = TRUE)  #> The observation with at most 0.05 probability at or below is 10  #> [1] 10  iscaminvbinom(alpha = 0.05, n = 30, prob = 0.5, lower.tail = FALSE)  #> The observation with at most 0.05 probability at or above is 20  #> [1] 20  iscaminvbinom(alpha = 0.01, n = 60, prob = 0.10, lower.tail = FALSE)  #> The observation with at most 0.01 probability at or above is 13  #> [1] 13

text: Inverse Normal Calculation

title: Inverse Normal Calculation — iscaminvnorm
text: prob1 probability find normal quantile . mean mean normal distribution. sd standard deviation normal distribution. Sd deprecated–available backwards compatibility. direction direction probability calculation: "", "", "outside", "". verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Inverse Normal Calculation — iscaminvnorm
text: plot normal distribution quantile specified probability highlighted.

title: Inverse Normal Calculation — iscaminvnorm
code: iscaminvnorm(0.05, direction = "below")  #> The observation with 0.05 probability below is -1.645  iscaminvnorm(0.90, mean = 100, sd = 15, direction = "above")  #> The observation with 0.9 probability above is 80.78  iscaminvnorm(0.10, direction = "outside")  #> There is 0.1 probability outside -1.645 and 1.645  iscaminvnorm(0.95, direction = "between")  #> There is 0.95 probability between -1.96 and 1.96

text: t value specified probability.

title: Inverse T Calculation — iscaminvt
code: iscaminvt(0.05, df = 15, direction = "below")  #> The observation with 0.05 probability below is -1.753  iscaminvt(0.10, df = 25, direction = "above")  #> The observation with 0.1 probability above is 1.316  iscaminvt(0.95, df = 30, direction = "between")  #> There is 0.95 probability between -2.042 and 2.042  iscaminvt(0.05, df = 20, direction = "outside")  #> There is 0.05 probability outside -2.086 and 2.086

text: p-value plot normal distribution shaded area representing probability observed value extreme occurring.

title: Normal Tail Probability — iscamnormprob
code: iscamnormprob(1.96, direction = "above")  #> probability: 0.025  #> Warning: "scipen" is not a graphical parameter #> Warning: "digits" is not a graphical parameter #> [1] "0.025" iscamnormprob(-1.5, mean = 1, sd = 2, direction = "below")  #> probability: 0.1056  #> Warning: "scipen" is not a graphical parameter #> Warning: "digits" is not a graphical parameter #> [1] "0.1056" iscamnormprob(0, xval2 = 1.5, direction = "between")  #> probability: 0.4332  #> Warning: "scipen" is not a graphical parameter #> Warning: "digits" is not a graphical parameter #> [1] "0.4332" iscamnormprob(-1, xval2 = 1, direction = "outside")  #> probability: 0.3173  #> Warning: "scipen" is not a graphical parameter #> Warning: "digits" is not a graphical parameter #> [1] "0.3173"

what: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
title: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
text: iscamonepropztest calculates one-proportion z-test /corresponding confidence interval.

title: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
code: iscamonepropztest(   observed,   n,   hypothesized = NULL,   alternative = "two.sided",   conf.level = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
text: observed observed number successes. value less 1 provided, assumed sample proportion. n sample size. hypothesized hypothesized probability success null hypothesis. optional parameter. alternative character string specifying form alternative hypothesis. Must one "less", "greater", "two.sided". optional parameter. conf.level confidence level(s) two-sided confidence interval. optional parameter. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
text: function prints results one-proportion z-test /confidence interval. also generates plots visualize test interval.

title: One Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamonepropztest
code: iscamonepropztest(observed = 35, n = 50, hypothesized = 0.5) #>  #> One Proportion z test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 35, sample size = 50, sample proportion = 0.7 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi = 0.5  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi <> 0.5  #> z-statistic: 2.828  #> p-value: 0.004678    iscamonepropztest(   observed = 0.8,   n = 100,   hypothesized = 0.75,   alternative = "greater",   conf.level = 0.95 ) #>  #> One Proportion z test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 80, sample size = 100, sample proportion = 0.8 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi = 0.75  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi > 0.75  #> z-statistic: 1.155  #> p-value: 0.1241   #> 95 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.7216014 ,  0.8783986 )   iscamonepropztest(observed = 60, n = 100, conf.level = 0.90) #>  #> One Proportion z test #>  #> Data: observed successes = 60, sample size = 100, sample proportion = 0.6 #>  #> 90 % Confidence interval for pi: ( 0.519419 ,  0.680581 )

title: One Sample T-Test — iscamonesamplet
text: onesamplet calculates one sample t-test /interval summary statistics. defaults hypothesized population mean 0. can optionally set alternative hypothesis confidence level two-sided confidence interval.

title: One Sample T-Test — iscamonesamplet
code: iscamonesamplet(   xbar,   sd,   n,   hypothesized = 0,   alternative = NULL,   conf.level = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: One Sample T-Test — iscamonesamplet
text: xbar Observed mean. sd Observed standard deviation. n Sample size. hypothesized Hypothesized population mean. alternative "less", "greater", "two.sided" conf.level Confidence level. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: One Sample T-Test — iscamonesamplet
text: t value, p value, confidence interval.

title: One Sample T-Test — iscamonesamplet
code: iscamonesamplet(   xbar = 2.5,   sd = 1.2,   n = 30,   alternative = "greater",   hypothesized = 2 ) #>  #> One Sample t test #>  #> mean = 2.5, sd = 1.2,  sample size = 30 #> Null hypothesis       : mu = 2  #> Alternative hypothesis: mu > 2  #> t-statistic: 2.282   #> p-value: 0.01499991  iscamonesamplet(   xbar = 10.3,   sd = 2,   n = 50,   alternative = "less",   hypothesized = 11 ) #>  #> One Sample t test #>  #> mean = 10.3, sd = 2,  sample size = 50 #> Null hypothesis       : mu = 11  #> Alternative hypothesis: mu < 11  #> t-statistic: -2.475   #> p-value: 0.00841815  iscamonesamplet(   xbar = 98.2,   sd = 2,   n = 100,   alternative = "two.sided",   conf.level = 0.95 ) #>  #> One Sample t test #>  #> mean = 98.2, sd = 2,  sample size = 100 #> Null hypothesis       : mu = 0  #> Alternative hypothesis: mu <> 0  #> t-statistic: 491   #> 95 % Confidence interval for mu: ( 97.80316 ,  98.59684 )  #> p-value: 1.824574e-169  iscamonesamplet(xbar = 55, sd = 5, n = 40, conf.level = 0.99) #>  #> One Sample t test #>  #> mean = 55, sd = 5,  sample size = 40 #> 99 % Confidence interval for mu: ( 52.85921 ,  57.14079 )

title: Some Summary Statistics — iscamsummary
text: summary calculates five number summary, mean, standard deviation quantitative variable x. optional second, categorical variable can specified values calculated separately group. number digits output can also specified. Skewness sample skewness: \(g_1 := \frac{m_3}{m_2^{3/2}}\), \(m_2 := \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n}(x_i - \bar{x})^2\) \(m_3 := \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n}(x_i - \bar{x})^3\) second third central sample moments.

title: Some Summary Statistics — iscamsummary
code: iscamsummary(x, explanatory = NULL, digits = 3)

title: Some Summary Statistics — iscamsummary
text: x data summarize. explanatory optional explanatory variable group . digits number digits round .

title: Some Summary Statistics — iscamsummary
text: table summary statistics x.

title: Some Summary Statistics — iscamsummary
code: set.seed(0) fake_data <- rnorm(30) # simulating some data groups <- sample(c("group1","group2"), 30, TRUE) iscamsummary(fake_data) #>   Missing  n   Min     Q1 Median    Q3   Max  Mean    SD Skewness #> 1       0 30 -1.54 -0.621 -0.031 0.487 2.405 0.022 0.914    0.441 iscamsummary(fake_data, explanatory = groups, digits = 2) # with groups #>        Missing  n   Min    Q1 Median   Q3  Max  Mean   SD Skewness #> group1       0 13 -1.24 -0.33  -0.06 0.44 1.26 -0.02 0.65     0.21 #> group2       0 17 -1.54 -0.89   0.13 0.76 2.40  0.05 1.09     0.38

title: Tail Probability for t-distribution — iscamtprob
text: Tail Probability t-distribution

title: Tail Probability for t-distribution — iscamtprob
code: iscamtprob(xval, df, direction, xval2 = NULL, verbose = TRUE)

title: Tail Probability for t-distribution — iscamtprob
text: xval observed value. df degrees freedom. direction direction probability calculation, "" ""; "outside" "" used, second larger observation, xval2 must specified xval2 second observation value. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Tail Probability for t-distribution — iscamtprob
text: tail probability specified direction using given parameters.

title: Tail Probability for t-distribution — iscamtprob
code: iscamtprob(xval = -2.05, df = 10, direction = "below")  #> probability: 0.03375  iscamtprob(xval = 1.80, df = 20, direction = "above")  #> [1] 1.8 #> [1] 5 #> probability: 0.04348  iscamtprob(xval = -2, xval2 = 2, df = 15, direction = "between")  #> probability: 0.9361  iscamtprob(xval = -2.5, xval2 = 2.5, df = 25, direction = "outside")  #> probability: 0.01934

what: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
title: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
text: iscamtwopropztest calculates two-proportion z-test /corresponding confidence interval.

title: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
code: iscamtwopropztest(   observed1,   n1,   observed2,   n2,   hypothesized = 0,   alternative = NULL,   conf.level = NULL,   datatable = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
text: observed1 observed number successes group 1. value less 1 provided, assumed sample proportion. n1 sample size group 1. observed2 observed number successes group 2. value less 1 provided, assumed sample proportion. n2 sample size group 2. hypothesized hypothesized difference probability success null hypothesis. optional parameter. alternative character string specifying form alternative hypothesis. Must one "less", "greater", "two.sided". optional parameter. conf.level confidence level(s) two-sided confidence interval. optional parameter. datatable two-way table counts alternative input method. optional parameter. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages

title: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
text: function prints results two-proportion z-test /confidence interval. also generates plots visualize test interval.

title: Two Proportion Z-Test and Interval — iscamtwopropztest
code: iscamtwopropztest(observed1 = 35, n1 = 50, observed2 = 28, n2 = 45) #>  #> Two Proportion z test #>  #> Group1: observed successes = 35, sample size = 50, sample proportion = 0.7 #>  #> Group2: observed successes = 28, sample size = 45, sample proportion = 0.6222 #>   iscamtwopropztest(   observed1 = 0.8,   n1 = 100,   observed2 = 0.6,   n2 = 80,   hypothesized = 0,   alternative = "greater",   conf.level = 0.95 ) #>  #> Two Proportion z test #>  #> Group1: observed successes = 80, sample size = 100, sample proportion = 0.8 #>  #> Group2: observed successes = 48, sample size = 80, sample proportion = 0.6 #>  #> Null hypothesis       : pi1-pi2 = 0  #> Alternative hypothesis: pi1-pi2 > 0  #> z-statistic: 2.942   #> 95 % Confidence interval for pi1-pi2: ( 0.06706878 ,  0.3329312 )  #> p-value: 0.001632   iscamtwopropztest(observed1 = 60, n1 = 100, observed2 = 45, n2 = 90, conf.level = 0.90) #>  #> Two Proportion z test #>  #> Group1: observed successes = 60, sample size = 100, sample proportion = 0.6 #>  #> Group2: observed successes = 45, sample size = 90, sample proportion = 0.5 #>  #> 90 % Confidence interval for pi1-pi2: ( -0.01835837 ,  0.2183584 )

title: Two Sample T-Test — iscamtwosamplet
text: twosamplet calculates two sample t-test /interval summary data. defaults hypothesized population mean difference 0. can optionally set alternative hypothesis confidence level two-sided confidence interval.

title: Two Sample T-Test — iscamtwosamplet
code: iscamtwosamplet(   x1,   sd1,   n1,   x2,   sd2,   n2,   hypothesized = 0,   alternative = NULL,   conf.level = 0,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Two Sample T-Test — iscamtwosamplet
text: x1 Observed mean group 1. sd1 Observed standard deviation group 1. n1 Sample size group 1. x2 Observed mean group 2. sd2 Observed standard deviation group 2. n2 Sample size group 2. hypothesized Hypothesized difference population means. alternative "less", "greater", "two.sided" conf.level Confidence level. verbose Logical, defaults TRUE. Set FALSE suppress messages iscamtwosamplet( x1 = 25, sd1 = 5, n1 = 40, x2 = 22, sd2 = 6, n2 = 45, alternative = "greater" ) iscamtwosamplet( x1 = 10, sd1 = 2, n1 = 50, x2 = 12, sd2 = 2.5, n2 = 50, alternative = "two.sided" ) iscamtwosamplet( x1 = 8, sd1 = 1.5, n1 = 30, x2 = 5, sd2 = 1.8, n2 = 33, alternative = "greater", hypothesized = 2 ) iscamtwosamplet( x1 = 15, sd1 = 3, n1 = 25, x2 = 12, sd2 = 3.5, n2 = 28, conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Two Sample T-Test — iscamtwosamplet
text: t value, p value, confidence interval.
